Analysis Project Planning & Stakeholder Updates

Emily Riederer

2018-12-31

Source: vignettes/analysis-projects.Rmd
analysis-projects.Rmd

Many people in the R community have shared their thoughts on how best to structure large analytical projects for ease of use and reproducibility. Much of the discussion has stemmed from academia, including Lucy D’Agostino McGowan’s blog post on organization a disertations, and Software Carpentry’s paper on best practices for research projects. However, these principles are also relevant to personal or enterprise work.

Since version control via git and sharing on GitHub are often recommended practices for these projects, it is natural to want to use GitHub for the project management component as well. In particular, project planning through GitHub enables natural communication to various consumers of your analysis, whether committee members (as Lucy describes) or business leaders.

In particular, Lucy emphasizes the importance of sending out an agenda before meetings and sharing minutes afterward, specifically recapping recently completed work and next steps. Such meetings are another good use for plans to make sure everyone is aligned with an analysts approach.

Planning Your Project

Writing out your plan of attack in YAML lets you foxus on key details and allows everything to remain easily editable while you refine your approach.

Recall the example plan discussed in the vignette on custom plans:

- title: Data cleaning and validation
  description: >
    We will conduct data quality checks,
    resolve issues with data quality, and
    document this process
  due_on: 2018-12-31T12:59:59Z
  issue:
    - title: Define data quality standards
      body: List out decision rules to check data quality
      assignees: [emilyriederer]
      labels: [a, b, c]
    - title: Assess data quality
      body: Use assertthat to test decision rules on dataset
      labels: [low]
    - title: Resolve data quality issues
      body: Conduct needed research to resolve any issues

- title: Exploratory data analysis
  description: >
    Create basic statistics and views to better
    understand dataset and relationships
  issue:
    - title: Summary statistics
      body: Calculate summary statistics
    - title: Visualizations
      body: Create univariate and bivariate plots

As described in the custom plans vignette, this could be added to a GitHub repo as issues and milestones with the post_plan() function.

Including in Meeting Reports

Meeting minutes or agendas can be added to agendas and minutes, such as Lucy’s templates provide, with the report_ functions.

plan_path <- system.file("extdata", "plan.yml", package = "ghtrackr", mustWork = TRUE)
my_plan <- read_plan(plan_path)
report_plan(my_plan)

Data cleaning and validation ( 0 % Complete - 0 / 3 Issues)

  • ☐ Define data quality standards
  • ☐ Assess data quality
  • ☐ Resolve data quality issues

Exploratory data analysis ( 0 % Complete - 0 / 2 Issues)

  • ☐ Summary statistics
  • ☐ Visualizations

Similarly, as items are accomplished, the complementary report_progress() function provides information on in-progress parts of your plan, pulled back down from GitHub.

issues <- 
  get_issues(analysis_repo, state = 'all', since = '2018-12-01') %>% 
  parse_issues() %>%
  filter(issues, milestone_created_at >='2018-12-25' & milestone_created_at <= '2018-12-31') %>%
  arrange(milestone_number)
report_progress(issues)

Data cleaning and validation ( 100 % Complete - 3 / 3 Issues)
  • ☑ Resolve data quality issues
  • ☑ Assess data quality
  • ☑ Define data quality standards
Exploratory data analysis ( 50 % Complete - 1 / 2 Issues)
  • ☐ Visualizations
  • ☑ Summary statistics
